article.title: Alaska_Native_Claims_Settlement_Act
article.paragraph: TheAlaska Native Claims Settlement Act(ANCSA) was signed into law byU.S. PresidentPresidentRichard M. Nixonon December 18, 1971, constituting at the time the largest land claims settlement inUnited States history.cite webThomasMonica E.The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act: Conflict and Controversyhttp://www.alaskool.org/projects/ancsa/articles/mthomas/ancsa_conflict.htmalaskool.orgPolar Record, 23(142): 27-36 (1986). Cambridge University Press.26 November 2014cite webKroernerClaudiaU.S. To Pay Navajo Nation $554 Million In Largest Tribal Settlement In Historyhttp://www.buzzfeed.com/claudiakoerner/us-to-pay-navajo-nation-554-million-in-largest-tribal-settlebuzzfeed.com26 November 2014ANCSA was intended to resolve long-standing issues surrounding aboriginal land claims in Alaska, as well as to stimulate economic development throughoutAlaska."Recognition of aboriginal land rights in Alaska was a sharp departure from American Indian policy in other parts of the US. Observers believe this was more a result of slow economic development within Alaska than rejection of Indian policy," citing Cooley, R.A. 1983. "Evolution of Alaska land policy." in Morehouse, T. A. (editor).Alaskan Resources Development: Issues of the 1980s. Boulder: Westview Press, pp. 13-49.The settlement establishedAlaska Nativeclaims to the land by transferring titles to twelveAlaska Native Regional CorporationsAlaska Native regional corporationsand over 200 local village corporations.A thirteenth regional corporation was later created for Alaska Natives who no longer resided inAlaska.The act is codified as 43 U.S.C. 1601 et seq.cite webhttp://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/43/chapter-33http://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/43/chapter-3343 U.S. Code Chapter 33Legal Information InstituteCornell University Law School27 November 2014
article.heading: Background
article.paragraph: When Alaska became a state in 1959, section 4 of theAlaska Statehood Actprovided that any existing Alaska Native land claims would be unaffected by statehood and held in status quo.cite webJonesRichard S.ALASKA NATIVE CLAIMS SETTLEMENT ACT OF 1971 (PUBLIC LAW 92-203): HISTORY AND ANALYSIS TOGETHER WITH SUBSEQUENT AMENDMENTS Report No. 81-127 GOVhttp://www.alaskool.org/projects/ancsa/reports/rsjones1981/ANCSA_History71_Ftnts.htm#28alaskool.org (June 1, 1981)29 November 2014cite webAlaska Statehood Act Public Law 85-508, 72 Stat. 339, July 7, 1958http://www.lbblawyers.com/ancsa/state6.htmlbblawyers.com29 November 2014Yet while section 4 of the act preserved Native land claims until later settlement, section 6 allowed for the state government to claim lands deemed vacant.Section 6 granted the state of Alaska the right to select lands then in the hands of the federal government, with the exception of Native territory, so that nearlyconvert104.5e6acrekm2from the public domain would eventually be transferred to the state.cite webRichard S.JonesALASKA NATIVE CLAIMS SETTLEMENT ACT OF 1971 (PUBLIC LAW 92-203): HISTORY AND ANALYSIS TOGETHER WITH SUBSEQUENT AMENDMENTS: Introductionhttp://www.alaskool.org/projects/ancsa/reports/rsjones1981/ancsa_history71.htmalaskool.org29 November 2014All the same, the state government attempted to acquire lands under section 6 of the Statehood Act that were subject to Native claims under section 4, and that were currently occupied and used by Alaska Natives.The federalBureau of Land Managementbegan to process the Alaska government's selections without taking into account the Native claims and without informing the affected Native groups.

It was against this backdrop that the original language for a land claims settlement was developed.cite webSTATEMENT OF RAY CHRISTIANSEN, STATE SENATOR FOR DISTRICT Khttp://www.alaskool.org/projects/ancsa/testimony/ancsa_hearings/r_christiansen.htmlalaskool.org29 November 2014In 1968, GovernorWalter Hickelsummoned a group of Native leaders to work out a settlement that would be satisfactory to Natives.The group met for ten days and asked for $20 million in exchange for requested lands.They also asked for 10% of federal mineral lease revenue.cite bookHaycoxStephen W.Frigid Embrace: Politics, Economics, and Environment in Alaska2002Oregon University Press087071536499–112http://books.google.com/books?ei29 November 2014

A 9.2-magnitude1964 Alaska earthquakeearthquakestruck the state in 1964.cite webThe Great Alaska Earthquake of 1964http://www.aeic.alaska.edu/quakes/Alaska_1964_earthquake.htmlAlaska Earthquake Center29 November 2014Recovery efforts drew the attention of the federal government, which found that Alaska Natives had the poorest living conditions in the country.The Federal Field Committee for Development Planning in Alaska decided that Natives should receive $100 million and the 10% revenue royalty.Nothing was done with this proposal, however, and a freeze on land transfers remained in effect.cite webGrabinskaKorneliaExcerpts from HISTORY OF EVENTS LEADING TO THE PASSAGE OF THE ALASKA NATIVE CLAIMS SETTLEMENT ACThttp://www.alaskool.org/projects/ancsa/tcc2/tananachiefs.html#B.%20Campaigns%20in%20the%20Congress,%201967-1971Tanana Chiefs Conference, Inc.29 November 2014In 1969 President Nixon appointed Hickel asUnited States Secretary of the InteriorSecretary of the Interior.cite web1 Testimony of Sealaska Corporation Native Regional Corporation for Southeast Alaska’s Tlingit, Haida, and Tsimshian People May 16, 2013http://docs.house.gov/meetings/ii/ii24/20130516/100839/hhrg-113-ii24-wstate-mallottb-20130516.pdfpp.41-6629 November 2014The Alaska Federation of Natives (AFN) protested against Hickels nomination, but he was eventually confirmed.

Hickel worked with the AFN, negotiating with Native leaders and state government over the disputed lands. Offers went back and forth, with each rejecting the others proposals.cite bookNaskeClaus-M.Alaska: A History of the 49th State1994University of Oklahoma Press080612573X202–205http://books.google.com/books?id29 November 2014The AFN wanted rights to land, while then GovernorKeith Harvey MillerKeith Millerbelieved Natives did not have legitimate claims to state land in light of the provisions of theAlaska Statehood Act.Yet soon thereafter a new Alaska state administration was to stake out positions upon which the AFN and other stakeholders could largely agree.cite bookHaycoxStephenAlaska: An American Colony2006University of Washington Press0295986298271–287http://books.google.com/books?id29 November 2014Native leaders, in addition to the Alaska's congressional delegation and the state's newly elected GovernorWilliam A. Egan, eventually reached the basis for presenting a common front to Congress.The proposed settlement terms faced challenges in both houses but found a strong ally in SenatorHenry M. Jacksonwho representedWashington state.The most controversial issues that continued to hold up approval were methods for determining land selection by Alaska Natives and financial distribution.

In 1968, theARCOAtlantic-Richfield Companydiscovered oil atPrudhoe Bay Oil FieldPrudhoe Bayon theArctic OceanArcticcoast, catapulting the issue ofland ownershipinto headlines.cite newsCoileZacherySan Francisco Chroniclehttp://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?fileARCTIC OIL: Oil is the lifeblood of Alaska, with residents ready to drillAugust 9, 20052005-09-12http://web.archive.org/web/20051003231635/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file3 October 2005nocite journalBanet (Jr.)Arthur C.Oil and Gas Development on Alaska's North Slope: Past Results and Future ProspectsOpen File Reports: Bureau of Land ManagementMarch 19916, 22http://www.blm.gov/pgdata/etc/medialib/blm/ak/aktest/ofr.Par.49987.File.dat/OFR_34.pdf30 November 2014In order to lessen the difficulty of drilling at such a remote location and transporting the oil to thelower 48 states, the oil companies proposed building a pipeline to carry the oil across Alaska to the port ofValdez, AlaskaValdezcite bookNaskeClaus-M.Alaska: A History of the 49th State1994University of Oklahoma Press080612573X241–269http://books.google.com/books?id30 November 2014At Valdez, the oil would be loaded onto tankers and shipped to the contiguous states.The plan had been approved, but a permit to construct the pipeline, which would cross lands involved in the land claims dispute, could not be granted until the Native claims were settled.

With major petroleum dollars on the line, there were new calls for a definitive legislative resolution at the federal level.cite webMorehouseThomas A.NATIVE CLAIMS AND POLITICAL DEVELOPMENT: A COMPARATIVE ANALYSIShttp://www.alaskool.org/projects/ancsa/international/tmwrsa1.html1987alaskool.org30 November 2014Thus in 1971, the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act was signed into law by President Nixon.It abrogated Native claims to aboriginal lands except those that are the subject of the law.cite webAlaska Native Claims Settlement ActU.S. Fish and Wildlife Servicehttp://laws.fws.gov/lawsdigest/alasnat.html2005-09-01http://web.archive.org/web/20050831174048/http://laws.fws.gov/lawsdigest/alasnat.html31 August 2005noIn return, Natives received up toconvert44e6acrekm2of land and were paid $963 million.The land and money were divided among regional, urban, and village tribal corporations.cite journalDixieDayoInstitutional innovation in less than ideal conditions: management of commons by an Alaska Native village corporationInternational Journal of the Commons201041http://www.thecommonsjournal.org/index.php/ijc/article/view/14630 November 2014cite web43 U.S.C. § 1602(o), "Urban Corporation"http://www.lbblawyers.com/ancsa/1602.htm30 November 2014
article.heading: Effect of land conveyances
article.paragraph: In 1971, barely one million acres of land in Alaska was in private hands.ANCSA together with section 6 ofAlaska Statehood Actwhich the act allowed to come to fruition affected ownership to aboutconvert148.5e6acrekm2of land in Alaska once wholly controlled by the federal government.That is larger byconvert6e6acrekm2than the combined areas ofMaine,Vermont,New Hampshire,Massachusetts,Rhode Island,Connecticut,New York,New Jersey,Pennsylvania,Delaware,MarylandandVirginia.cite newsAreas As Vast As Whole States Now Change Hands In Alaska[[New York Times]]October 8, 1982http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res

When the bill passed in 1971, it included provisions that had never been attempted in United States settlements with Native Americans.The newly passed Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act created twelve Native regional economic development corporations.Each corporation was associated with a specific region of Alaska, and the Natives who had traditionally lived there.This innovative approach to native settlements engaged the tribes in corporate capitalism.cite journalLinxwilerJames D.Chapter 12 THE ALASKA NATIVE CLAIMS SETTLEMENT ACT AT 35: DELIVERING ON THE PROMISEANCSA at 3520073–5http://www.lbblawyers.com/ancsa/ANCSA%20at%2035%20Delivering%20on%20the%20Promise%20Proof%2010-25-07.pdf1 December 2014It was the idea of the AFN, who believed that the Natives would have to become a part of the capitalist system in order to survive.As stockholders in these corporations, the Natives could earn some income and stay in their traditional villages.cite bookDombrowskiKirkAgainst Culture: Development, Politics, and Religion in Indian Alaska2001U of Nebraska Press080326632475http://books.google.com/books?id1 December 2014If the corporations were managed properly, they could make profits that would enable individuals to stay, rather than having to leave Native villages to find better work.This was intended to help preserve Native culture.cite bookHaycoxStephen W.Frigid Embrace: Politics, Economics, and Environment in Alaska2002Oregon University Press0870715364132–133http://books.google.com/books?ei29 November 2014
article.heading: Native and state land selection
article.paragraph: Alaska Natives had three years from passage of ANCSA to make land selections of theconvert44e6acrekm2granted under the act.cite web43 U.S. Code § 1611 - Native land selectionshttp://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/43/1611Legal Information Institute30 November 2014In some cases corporations received outside aid in surveying the land.For instance,Doyon, Limited(one of the 13Alaska native corporationregional corporations) was helped by the Geophysical Institute of theUniversity of Alaska.The Institute determined which land contained resources such as minerals and coal.NASAsimilarly provided satellite imagery to aid in finding areas most suited for vegetation and subsistence.The imagery also showed locations of caribou and moose, as well as forests with marketable timber.In total aboutconvert7e6acrekm2were analyzed for Doyon.Natives were able to choose tens of thousands of acres of land rich with timber while Doyon used mineral analysis to attract businesses.cite journalHaynesJames B.Land Selection and Development under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement ActArctic Institute of North AmericaSeptember 1975283201–208http://pubs.aina.ucalgary.ca/arctic/Arctic28-3-201.pdf30 November 2014

The state of Alaska to date has been granted approximately 85% orconvert90e6acrekm2of the land claims it has made under ANCSA.cite webFact Sheet Title: Land Ownership In Alaska (March 2000)http://dnr.alaska.gov/mlw/factsht/land_own.pdfAlaska Department of Natural Resources30 November 2014The state is entitled to a total ofconvert104.5e6acrekm2under the terms of the Statehood Act.Originally the state had 25 years after passage of theAlaska Statehood Actto file claims under section 6 of the act with theBureau of Land Management(BLM).cite webAlaska Statehood Act: Selection of public lands, fish and wildlife, public schools, mineral permits, mineral grants, confirmation of grants, internal improvements, submerged lands (Section 6)http://www.lbblawyers.com/ancsa/state6.htm30 November 2014Amendments to ANCSA extended that deadline until 1994 with the expectation that BLM would complete processing of land transfers subject to overlapping Native claims by 2009.cite web118 STAT. 3594 (PUBLIC LAW 108–452—DEC. 10, 2004) 43 USC 1635 notehttp://www.blm.gov/wo/st/en/info/regulations/alaska_specific_legislation.-WidePar-35782-DownloadFile.tmp/PL108-2-452.pdf30 November 2014Nonetheless, some Native and state selections under ANCSA remained unresolved as late as December 2014.cite webRuskinLizSealaska Selections in Tongass Added to Defense Billhttp://www.alaskapublic.org/2014/12/03/sealaska-selections-in-tongass-added-to-defense-bill/Alaska Public Media4 December 2014
article.heading: Criticism of ANCSA
article.paragraph: There was largely positive reaction to ANCSA, although not entirely.cite webInterview of Margie Brownhttp://www.litsite.org/index.cfm?sectionLitSite AlaskaUniversity of Alaska Anchorage1 December 2014cite bookBornemanWalter R.Alaska: Saga of a Bold Land2009Zondervan0061865273470–472http://books.google.com/books?id1 December 2014The act was supported by Natives as well as non-Natives, and likewise enjoyed bipartisan support.cite webMyersEric F.Letter to Rep. Don Young dated May 15, 2013http://ak.audubon.org/sites/default/files/documents/representative_young_-_sealaska_hr_740_5-15-13_final.pdfAudubon Alaska1 December 2014Natives were heavily involved in the legislative process, and the final draft of the act used many AFN ideas.cite webHistoryhttp://www.nativefederation.org/about-afn/history/Alaska Federation of Natives1 December 2014Much criticism of ANCSA all the same has come from Natives who in some cases argued that it hastened cultural genocide.cite bookHaycoxStevenAlaska: An American Colony2006University of Washington Press0295986298xiiihttp://books.google.com/books?id1 December 2014cite bookWilliamsMaria Sháa TláaThe Alaska Native Reader: History, Culture, Politics2009Duke University Press0822390833180–181http://books.google.com/books?id1 December 2014Some Natives critiqued ANCSA as an illegitimate treaty since only tribal leaders were involved and the provisions of the act were not voted on by indigenous populations.One native even described it as a social and political experiment.Critics have also argued that Natives feared massacre or incarceration and offered no resistance only for that reason.Others have argued that the settlement was arguably the most generous afforded by the United States to a Native group, and point out that some of the largest and most profitable corporations in the state are the twelve created by ANCSA.cite bookBornemanWalter R.Alaska: Saga of a Bold Land2009Zondervan0061865273528–529http://books.google.com/books?id1 December 2014Some in Alaska cried "Native welfare!" and indeed these complaints continue to be heard.The corporation system has been critiqued, as stockholders have sold land to outside corporations who have leveled forests and extracted minerals.cite webRobert W. Rudehttp://www.litsite.org/index.cfm?sectionLitSite AlaskaUniversity of Alaska Anchorage1 December 2014But supporters of the system argue that it has provided economic benefits for indigenous peoples that outweigh these consequences.cite webAlaska’s Native Corporationshttp://www.akrdc.org/issues/nativecorporations/overview.htmlResource Development Council for Alaska, Inc.1 December 2014cite bookRoderick (Ed.)LibbyDo Alaska Native People Get Free Medical Care?2008University of Alaska Anchorage and Alaska Pacific University978-1-4276-3215-924http://www.uaa.alaska.edu/books-of-the-year/year08-09/upload/Book108-09.pdf1 December 2014
article.heading: Selected provisions of ANCSA

list.listitem: Alaska NativeNativeclaims in Alaska were extinguished by means of section 4 of ANCSA.cite journalLinxwilerJames D.Chapter 12 THE ALASKA NATIVE CLAIMS SETTLEMENT ACT AT 35: DELIVERING ON THE PROMISEANCSA at 3520075http://www.lbblawyers.com/ancsa/ANCSA%20at%2035%20Delivering%20on%20the%20Promise%20Proof%2010-25-07.pdf1 December 2014

In exchange for abrogating Native claims, approximately one-ninth of the state's land plus $962.5 million were distributed to more than 200 local Alaska NativeAlaska Native Regional Corporations"village corporations"established under section 8, in addition to 12 land-owning for-profit Alaska NativeAlaska Native Regional Corporations"regional corporations"and a non-land-owning thirteenth corporation for Alaska Natives who had left the state established under section 6.cite journalLinxwilerJames D.Chapter 12 THE ALASKA NATIVE CLAIMS SETTLEMENT ACT AT 35: DELIVERING ON THE PROMISEANCSA at 3520072–6http://www.lbblawyers.com/ancsa/ANCSA%20at%2035%20Delivering%20on%20the%20Promise%20Proof%2010-25-07.pdf1 December 2014

Of the compensation monies, $462.5 million was to come from the federal treasury and the rest from oil revenue-sharing.cite journalLinxwilerJames D.Chapter 12 THE ALASKA NATIVE CLAIMS SETTLEMENT ACT AT 35: DELIVERING ON THE PROMISEANCSA at 35200716–17)http://www.lbblawyers.com/ancsa/ANCSA%20at%2035%20Delivering%20on%20the%20Promise%20Proof%2010-25-07.pdf1 December 2014

Settlement benefits would accrue to those with at least one-fourth Native ancestry under sections 3(b) and 5(a).cite journalLinxwilerJames D.Chapter 12 THE ALASKA NATIVE CLAIMS SETTLEMENT ACT AT 35: DELIVERING ON THE PROMISEANCSA at 3520076 (note 21)http://www.lbblawyers.com/ancsa/ANCSA%20at%2035%20Delivering%20on%20the%20Promise%20Proof%2010-25-07.pdf1 December 2014

Of the approximately 80,000 Natives enrolled under ANCSA, those living in villages (approximately two-thirds of the total) would receive 100 shares in both a village and a regional corporation.cite bookMaddenRyanAlaska: On-the-road histories2005Interlink Books1566565669250http://books.google.com/books?id1 December 2014

The remaining one-third would be "at large" shareholders with 100 shares in aThe 13th Regional Corporationregional corporationwith additional rights to revenue from regional mineral and timber resources.

TheAlaska Native Allotment Actwas revoked but with the proviso that pending claims under that act would continue to be processed under section 18.cite journalLinxwilerJames D.Chapter 12 THE ALASKA NATIVE CLAIMS SETTLEMENT ACT AT 35: DELIVERING ON THE PROMISEANCSA at 35200733–34http://www.lbblawyers.com/ancsa/ANCSA%20at%2035%20Delivering%20on%20the%20Promise%20Proof%2010-25-07.pdf1 December 2014Successful applicants would be excluded under ANCSA by section 14(h)(5) from land to be used for a primary residence.
The twelve regional corporations within the state would administer the settlement.
AThe 13th Regional Corporationthirteenth corporationcomposed of Natives who had left the state would receive compensation but not land.

Surface rights toconvert44e6acrekm2were patented to the Native village and regional corporations under sections 12(c), as well as 14(h)(1) and (8).cite journalLinxwilerJames D.Chapter 12 THE ALASKA NATIVE CLAIMS SETTLEMENT ACT AT 35: DELIVERING ON THE PROMISEANCSA at 35200727http://www.lbblawyers.com/ancsa/ANCSA%20at%2035%20Delivering%20on%20the%20Promise%20Proof%2010-25-07.pdf1 December 2014

The surface rights to the patented land were granted to the village corporations and the subsurface right to the land were granted to the regional corporation, creating asplit estatepursuant to section 14(f).

article.heading: Alaska Native regional corporations

link.part: Regional corporations established by the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act.

listitem.italics: Main article at:Alaska Native Regional Corporations

article.paragraph: The following thirteen regional corporations were created under ANCSA:

Many regional corporations (and indeed some village corporations) have created their own nonprofits supported by the profits of their corporate undertakings.cite journalWorlRositaReconstructing Sovereignty in AlaskaCultural Survival QuarterlyFall 2001http://www.culturalsurvival.org/ourpublications/csq/article/reconstructing-sovereignty-alaska30 November 2014The objectives of these nonprofits are varied, but focus generally on cultural and educational activities.These include scholarships for Native students, sponsorship of cultural and artistic events, preservation efforts for Native languages and protection of sites with historic or religious importance.
article.heading: Alaska Native village and urban corporations
article.paragraph: ANCSA created about 224 village and urban corporations.cite webSearch Page for Alaska Native Region - Village - Corporation Indexhttp://dnr.alaska.gov/mlw/trails/17b/corpindex.cfmAlaska Department of Natural Resources1 December 2014Below is a representative list of village and urban corporations created under ANCSA:

list.listitem: Ukpeavik Iupiat Corporation, village corporation forBarrow, AlaskaBarrow
Bethel Native Corporation, village corporation forBethel, AlaskaBethel
Cape Fox Corporation, village corporation forSaxman, AlaskaSaxman
Deloycheet, Inc., village corporation forHoly Cross, AlaskaHoly Cross
Huna Totem Corporation, village corporation forHoonah, AlaskaHoonah
Haida Corporation, village corporation forHydaburg, AlaskaHydaburg
Goldbelt, Inc., urban corporation forJuneau, AlaskaJuneau
Paug-Vik, Inc. Ltd., village corporation forNaknek
Chenega Corporation, village corporation forChenega, AlaskaChenega
Afognak Native Corporation, village corporation forAfognakandPort Lions
Kavilco Incorporated, village corporation forKasaan
Klukwan, Inc., village corporation forKlukwan

The Kuskokwim Corporation, village corporation forAniak,Crooked Creek, AlaskaCrooked Creek,Georgetown, AlaskaGeorgetown,Upper Kalskag, AlaskaKalskag,Lower Kalskag,Napaimute,Red Devil, AlaskaRed Devil,Russian Mission, AlaskaRussian Mission,SleetmuteandStony River, AlaskaStony River
Natives of Kodiak, Inc., urban corporation forKodiak, AlaskaKodiak
Ounalashka Corporation, village corporation forUnalaska
Ouzinkie Native Corporation, village corporation forOuzinkie
Shee Atika, Incorporated, urban corporation forSitka, AlaskaSitka
